Thanks Gordon. I'll hold up on this planned article awhile to see what turn=
s up. I'd be most interested to learn when the "squirrel" started to be use=
d with the grape motif, realizing how ancient the grape motif is and its Gr=
eek origin and Buddist connection. 

Ron

  ----- Original Message ----- 
 =
 From: robsongo 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Wednesday, Jul=
y 08, 2009 10:45 PM
  Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Fw: Sword term meaning...=






  Hi Ron,

  Grapes are a motif that was brought in on the silk road =
and are of Greek
  origin, I would suspect. The famous set of Asuka period =
bronze statues of
  Yakushi nyorai and Gakko and Nikko at Yakushi-ji in Nar=
a have an early
  example of the grape motif on the base of the Yakushi nyo=
rai statue, so we
  are talking middle 500s or so. Squirrels may be include=
d in the motif, but I
  can't recall right off hand. Thus, there is a defin=
ite Buddhist connection.
  The motif shows up in sword fittings rather earl=
y and I believe there are
  pieces by Joshin or at least around that time w=
ith the motif. Ko-Kinko
  workers produced it, and there are also some Ko-M=
ino examples, if memory
  serves. As you move into the Edo period, it seems=
 to me that the motif was
  not as popular. Certainly from the mid to late =
Edo period you do not see it
  very much. If I can remember, I will see wha=
t some of my other sources have
  to say. I did see your earlier message ab=
out this, but just didn't jump at
  it.

  Sorry we will miss you in SF, bu=
t we can catch up at the Daitoken-ishi.

  Gordon

  _____ 

  From: nihont=
ostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
  Behalf Of=
 Ron Hartmann
  Sent: Thursday, July 09, 2009 10:28 AM
  To: nihontostudy@y=
ahoogroups.com
  Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Fw: Sword term meaning...

  T=
hanks for the reply, Gordon. As for SF show, I'm passing on it this time
  =
around unless...well, I'm always tempted, you know. Have booked my flight t=
o
  Japan this fall and this year it'll be two weeks, so with the exchange =
rate
  these days...one must be practical with unnecessary trips. Always en=
joy the
  social end of the shows, but nobody is buying anything off tables=
, so it
  seems.

  While I have your ears...or should I say, eyess...I jus=
t put together a
  little article for the JSS/US on the theme of "squirrel =
and grape vines."
  Surprisingly enough, I found not a lot on the subject o=
n-line and
  definitely, not in books. Care to give your opinion of what th=
is theme
  stands for?????? Sorry, couldn't resist asking!

  Regards to th=
e family....Ron
  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: robsongo 
  To: nih=
ontostudy@ <mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com> yahoogroups.com 
  Sent:=
 Wednesday, July 08, 2009 6:14 PM
  Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Fw: Sword t=
erm meaning...

  Hi Ron,

  The method of attaching menuki to the handle w=
ent from the male-female posts
  or iny=F4kon that passed through the handl=
e and the nakago fastening the
  menuki to each other to chikara-gane. Thes=
e iny=F4kon posts continued until
  the late Muromachi period into the Momo=
yama period. They are also seen on
  generally high class works for the mid=
 to late Edo period; however, they no
  longer went all the way through the=
 tsuka and basically worked as the newer
  chikara-gane do. As noted, stren=
gth and metal is the literal translation,
  but more accurately I would cal=
l them reinforced/strengthened tabs of
  typically copper. On an added note=
, at least the first three generations of
  the main line Goto masters are =
said to have only used iny=F4kon posts and
  menuki without them will typic=
ally be attributed to Ko-Goto rather than one
  of the main guys. I expect =
we will be catching up with many on the list in
  San Francisco next month.=
 I am certainly looking forward to it.

  Gordon

  _____

  nihontostu=

  Subject: [nihontostudy] Fw: Sword term meaning...

  Okay, I jumped to=
o soon on this question. I just found this described in
  Harry's translati=
on of Nihonto Kozo Vol. 6 in his glossery (page Glossery
  3):

  "Chikarag=
ane: Reinforcement tabs on the back of the menuki. Chikara means
  strength=
, Gane is metal." 

  Interesting! 

  Ron
  STL

  ----- Original Message =
----- 
  From: Ron Hartmann 
  To: TOKEN ; nihontostudy ; nihonto@yahoogrou=
ps
  <mailto:nihonto%40yahoogroups.com> .com 
  Sent: Wednesday, July 08, 2=
009 1:06 PM
  Subject: Sword term meaning...

  What does the term "chikara=
 gane" mean when refering to the back of menuki?
  On something AY translat=
ed for me decades ago he wrote, "...in the base,
  chikara gane comes to be=
 used." This is a translation describing menuki from
  mid-Edo period. (Kin=
ko Mino bori p.109)

  Ron
  STL
